descendants.content:
@ovid
For those interested, the scanned LIFE magazine this comes from is on Google Books:
https://books.google.nl/books?id=k00EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA1&dq=life%20magazine%201962%20february&pg=PA92#v=onepage&q=life%20magazine%201962%20february&f=true

I dug into some of the science reporting in LIFE editions from the 1960s for my PhD and the ads are a wonderful blast of the horrible past full of happy housewives with frozen meals and cigarette ads galore. Some of the photography and articles are excellent though - and many of the predictions in their science series “The Era of Rebuilt People” were surprisingly accurate.

account.note:
I am a #scientist studying how stressed cells in our body talk to other cells when tumours arise and when we age. Specifically, I look at how variations in the cellular stress response #senescence shape health using highly multiplexed imaging.
Problem solving using #Rstats keeps me happy, and the #OpenScience movement gives me faith that not all is lost in academia. You might find me wandering through greenhouses, reminiscing about #Morrowind or avenging Jean-Baptiste de Lamarck.

card.title: LIFE
card.description: LIFE Magazine is the treasured photographic magazine that chronicled the 20th Century. It now lives on at LIFE.com, the largest, most amazing collection of professional photography on the internet. Users can browse, search and view photos of today’s people and events. They have free access to share, print and post images for personal use.

media_attachments.description:
A full-page ad for Union Carbide from before the infamous Bhopal disaster, showing the Bhopal plant in the background, by a body of water, and watercolour figures tilling a field in the foreground with a team of two oxen.  A giant white man's hand is superimposed, pouring some kind of red liquid from a test tube onto the ground.

The ad copy beneath reads as follows:

 Science helps build a new India 

Oxen working the fields . . . the eternal river Ganges . . . jeweled elephants on parade. Today these symbols of ancient India exist side by side with a new sight —modern industry. India has developed bold new plans to build its economy and bring the promise of a bright future to its more than 400,000,000 people. » But India needs the technical knowledge of the western world. For example, working with Indian engineers and technicians, Union Carbide recently made available its vast scientific resources to help build a major chemicals and plastics plant near Bombay. » Throughout the free world, Union Carbide has been actively engaged in building plants for the manufacture of chemicals, plastics, carbons, gases, and metals. The people of Union Carbide welcome the opportunity to use their knowledge and skills in partnership with the citizens of so many great countries.
 
 A HAND IN THINGS TO COME

account.note:
I am not from Twitter, and I don't like the culture that arose from that site.

I do understand the lure of the shitpost, but I don't think it does anything good for anyone.

I like philosophy, although I am wrong about everything (from your perspective).

I believe that people who like logic don't tend to understand logic.

I believe there are bullets that must be bitten, but not at any cost.

I am opposed to fascism, and believe there are natural limits to all freedoms, also of speech.
